stateCorrectness.name: Fraud proofs are not enabled
stateCorrectness.description: OP Stack projects can use the OP fault proof system, already being deployed on some. This project though is not using fault proofs yet and is relying on the honesty of the permissioned Proposer and Challengers to ensure state correctness. The smart contract system permits invalid state roots.

risks.text: an invalid state root is submitted to the system.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, deleteL2Outputs function

dataAvailability.name: All data required for proofs is published on chain
dataAvailability.description: All the data that is used to construct the system state is published on chain in the form of cheap blobs or calldata. This ensures that it will be available for enough time.

references.text: Derivation: Batch submission - OP Mainnet specs
OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, depositTransaction function

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.text: L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, CHALLENGER address
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER address

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, depositTransaction function

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is finalized the funds become available for withdrawal on L1. The process of block finalization takes a challenge period of 7d to complete. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds. This transaction requires a merkle proof.

risks.text: the centralized validator goes down. Users cannot produce blocks themselves and exiting the system requires new block production.

references.text: OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, proveWithdrawalTransaction function
OptimismPortal.sol - Etherscan source code, finalizeWithdrawalTransaction function
L2OutputOracle.sol - Etherscan source code, PROPOSER check

exitMechanisms.name: Forced exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular exit they can submit their withdrawal requests directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request or halt all withdrawals, including forced withdrawals from L1 and regular withdrawals initiated on L2. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular exit.

references.text: Forced withdrawal from an OP Stack blockchain

otherConsiderations.name: EVM compatible smart contracts are supported
otherConsiderations.description: OP stack chains are pursuing the EVM Equivalence model. No changes to smart contracts are required regardless of the language they are written in, i.e. anything deployed on L1 can be deployed on L2.

permissions.name: Challenger
permissions.description: Challenger is an actor allowed to challenge or delete state roots proposed by a Proposer.

permissions.name: Guardian
permissions.description: Guardian is an actor allowed to pause deposits and withdrawals.

permissions.name: Proposer
permissions.description: Proposer is an actor allowed to post new state roots of the current layer to the host chain.

permissions.name: Sequencer
permissions.description: Sequencer is an actor allowed to commit transactions from the current layer to the host chain.

permissions.name: GelatoMultisig
permissions.description:
* A Gnosis Safe with 4 / 8 threshold. 
* Member of LiskRollupOwnerMultisig.
* A Challenger.
* Can change the configuration of SystemConfig - it can update the preconfer address, the batch submitter (Sequencer) address and the gas configuration of the system.
* Can change the configuration of AddressManager (acting via ProxyAdmin, LiskRollupOwnerMultisig) - set and change address mappings.
* A Guardian.
* Can upgrade the implementation of SystemConfig, L2OutputOracle, SuperchainConfig, OptimismPortal, L1ERC721Bridge, OptimismMintableERC20Factory (acting via ProxyAdmin, LiskRollupOwnerMultisig).
* Can upgrade the implementation of L1StandardBridge (acting via ProxyAdmin, LiskRollupOwnerMultisig) - upgrading the bridge implementation can give access to all funds escrowed therein.

permissions.name: LiskRollupOwnerMultisig
permissions.description:
* A Gnosis Safe with 1 / 1 threshold. 
* Can act on behalf of ProxyAdmin.

addresses.name: SystemConfig
addresses.description: Contains configuration parameters such as the Sequencer address, gas limit on this chain and the unsafe block signer address.

addresses.name: L2OutputOracle
addresses.description: Contains a list of proposed state roots which Proposers assert to be a result of block execution. Currently only the PROPOSER address can submit new state roots.

addresses.name: L1StandardBridge
addresses.description: The main entry point to deposit ERC20 tokens from host chain to this chain. This contract can store any token.

addresses.name: SuperchainConfig
addresses.description: This is NOT the shared SuperchainConfig contract of the OP stack Superchain but rather a local fork. It manages the `PAUSED_SLOT`, a boolean value indicating whether the local chain is paused, and `GUARDIAN_SLOT`, the address of the guardian which can pause and unpause the system.

addresses.name: OptimismPortal
addresses.description: The main entry point to deposit funds from host chain to this chain. It also allows to prove and finalize withdrawals.

addresses.name: AddressManager
addresses.description: Legacy contract used to manage a mapping of string names to addresses. Modern OP stack uses a different standard proxy system instead, but this contract is still necessary for backwards compatibility with several older contracts.

addresses.name: L1CrossDomainMessenger
addresses.description: Sends messages from host chain to this chain, and relays messages back onto host chain. In the event that a message sent from host chain to this chain is rejected for exceeding this chain's epoch gas limit, it can be resubmitted via this contract's replay function.

addresses.name: L1ERC721Bridge
addresses.description: Used to bridge ERC-721 tokens from host chain to this chain.

addresses.name: OptimismMintableERC20Factory
addresses.description: A helper contract that generates OptimismMintableERC20 contracts on the network it's deployed to. OptimismMintableERC20 is a standard extension of the base ERC20 token contract designed to allow the L1StandardBridge contracts to mint and burn tokens. This makes it possible to use an OptimismMintablERC20 as this chain's representation of a token on the host chain, or vice-versa.

addresses.name: L1OpUSDCBridgeAdapter
addresses.description: Escrow for USDC that uses the canonical bridge for messaging but is governed externally.

addresses.name: ProxyAdmin
addresses.description:
* Can be used to configure AddressManager  - set and change address mappings.
* Can be used to upgrade implementation of SystemConfig, L2OutputOracle, SuperchainConfig, OptimismPortal, L1ERC721Bridge, OptimismMintableERC20Factory.
* Can be used to upgrade implementation of L1StandardBridge  - upgrading the bridge implementation can give access to all funds escrowed therein.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

reasonsForBeingOther.label: No proofs
reasonsForBeingOther.shortDescription: The proof system isn't fully functional
reasonsForBeingOther.description: Projects without a proper proof system fully rely on single entities to safely update the state. A malicious proposer can finalize an invalid state, which can cause loss of funds.

display.name: Lisk
display.description: Lisk is an OP stack rollup on Ethereum that migrated from the L1 blockchain of the same name.

warnings.stateUpdates: Please note, for Optimistic rollups the state is not finalized until the challenge period passes.

liveness.explanation: Lisk is an Optimistic rollup that posts transaction data to the L1. For a transaction to be considered final, it has to be posted within a tx batch on L1 that links to a previous finalized batch. If the previous batch is missing, transaction finalization can be delayed up to 12h or until it gets published. The state root gets finalized 7d after it has been posted.

timeToInclusion.value: It's assumed that transaction data batches are submitted sequentially.

contract.description: Main entry point for users depositing ETH.
Main entry point for users depositing ERC20 token that do not require custom gateway.

contract.name: External USDC Vault
contract.description: Custom externally governed escrow for USDC bridged to Lisk.

layer.description: The data is posted to Ethereum as calldata or blobs.

bridge.description: The validating bridge has access to all the data, as it is posted onchain.

stateValidation.description: Currently the system permits invalid state roots. More details in project overview.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There is a 12h delay on this operation.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

requirements: The proof system is still under development.

Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.

requirements.description: The project calls itself a rollup.
State roots are posted to Ethereum L1.
Inputs for the state transition function are posted to Ethereum L1.

A source-available node exists that can recreate the state from Ethereum L1 data. Please note that the L2BEAT team has not verified the validity of the node source code. [View code](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/tree/develop/op-node)
The proof system is still under development.
Users' withdrawals can be censored by the permissioned operators.
Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.
Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.
